posts.name: Ohad
posts.cooked: so my team is trying to make an extending intake design using a rack and pinion (string slides will only go as far as the spool is and we’re having trouble with our linkage) but i ran into the issue of where to put the actual rack, since motor has to be perpendicular to the rack i was thinking of two solutions, putting the motor between the sides of our misumis and using timing belts to power two racks on opposite sides and using a motor to power an axle which holds a bevel gear connecting to the racks, however im unsure how one would do that, or if its even a good idea, help please

posts.name: Eren Orhun
posts.cooked: im not sure if i get your description right but i suggest looking at 125, 254 and 9483’s (offseason) 2023 robot. they all used the same intake concept *edit: i just saw that 5987 has this type of intake you can look at them too

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
5987 is using a rack-and-pinion intake this year. We haven’t finished putting it through its paces, but it’s working well so far. You can see pictures, testing videos, and robot CAD on our OA build thread.

FRC 5987 Galaxia | 2025 Build Thread | Open Alliance FRC Open Alliance

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Ohad
posts.cooked: i have finished the machanism, just a regular rack and pinion for now. my original question was whether a gear rack could be powered by bevels?

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
It would need to be a bevel gear itself. This would make it very expensive.

The usual solution would be to use a right angle gearbox as the last reduction stage before the pinion.

posts.name: hrench
posts.cooked:
We made our elevator this year with a rack and pinion of sorts.  Actually, two, because we put them on both sides to even out the force and discourage jamming.

We just used telescoping aluminum tubes with slots manually machined into the sides, then used a 50-size sprocket as the rack.

We kept our elevator-weight and inertia really low and it can move really fast.  Also, only need one NEO to run it at 12:1 ratio.

Think it will be good.

Any chance you can post a pic of this bevel-gear rack? I’m having trouble visualizing.

posts.name: Ohad
posts.cooked: I have solved the issue since. And I have never actually encountered a bevel rack. I was hoping to design one and wanted help

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: I bevel gear rack is not physically possible, but there really isn’t much reason for one any way. Rack and pinions turn rotary motion into linear motion, so there is no second axis of rotation to be out of parallel with the pinion.

posts.name: Ohad
posts.cooked: I was trying to replace the pinion with a bevel gear. Still wondering wether that would work

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: No, that is exactly what is impossible.

posts.name: Erik Boyle
posts.cooked:
If one were especially dedicated to this idea of putting a motor shaft in-plane with the rack motion, a worm gear rack is possible.

Not that I would ever recommend that solution in the FRC context.
